I should therefore <s>feel inclined to<\s> view this isolated case of the occurrence 
of the most arctic of all the ruminants on the banks of the 
Thames during the tie of the deposits of the Lower Brickearths 
as altogether exeptiona<s>ble<\s>l and not affecting the sum of the evidence 
as to climate afforded by Rhinoceros Megarhinus, R. leptorhinus, of Owen, 
Cervus Elephus. C. capreolus, Elephas antiquus E. priscus, Hippopotamus 
Major and indeed all the other Mammalia of the group found at 
Ilford, Grays Thurrock, or Erith. We have now quoted all the 
localities on record where the remains of the fossil animal 
have been found. In Eschscholtz Bay, Siberia Germany and France it is found in deposits of the late Geological age, and 
associated with a Postglacial group of Mammals, Reindeer 
Mammoth, Tichorine Rhinoceros and the like. In England 
also three out of four cases of its occurrence are in postglacial 
gravel beds. While the fourth relegates it to a vastly more 
ancient epoch in which characteristic preglacial and 
Pliocene <s>with characteristic<\s> postglacial mammals lived 
side by side in the valley of the Thames.
